list.item: QsP is particularly close to Basel F III 10

msItem.title: Fragment of a commentary on DC
msItem.note: According to Lohr, the fragment of a commentary on DC at ff. 100ra-102ra is Versoris's text. However, neither the titles of the questions nor their content correspond to Versoris'commentary. The structure of these questions is indeed similar to that of Versoris’s commentary, with notabilia, conclusions and doubts.

msItem.title: Utrum corpus mobile ad locum sit subiectum scientie libri De celo et mundo
Utrum totum, omne et perfectum sint determinata tribus vicibus: principio, medio et fine
Utrum mundus sit magnitudo perfecta
msItem.note: Only the title was copied, but not the question
Expositio cum questionibus

msItem.title: Utrum scientia de anima sit pars philosophie naturalis
Utrum omnis notitia sit de numero bonorum honorabiliorum
Utrum scientia de anima sit de numero difficiliorum
msItem.note: Incomplete

list.item: The first commentary is very similar to the DA commentary transmitted in ms. Basel F I 13: the questions transmitted are the same; the structure is the same; it could be a copy of this text.

msItem.author: Lambertus de Monte
msItem.title: Copulata super tres libros De anima Aristotelis iuxta doctrinam Thomae Aquinatis
msItem.note: QdA is followed by the edition of Lambertus de Monte's Questions on the same text (Hain 11583)
Cologne editions of QdC, QsM, QdG and QPN printed by Molner in 1485.

origin.p: The watermark P is similar to Piccard XII 81 and 155, both used in Cologne in 1486. This dating and origin could be confirmed a) by the date of the editions inserted in the codex, all printed in 1485; b) by the fact that the ms. contains, above Versoris’s text, Lambertus de Monte’s Questions on De anima, a thomistic commentary used in Cologne.

msItem.title: QsMete
msItem.note: The QsMete is interrupted at question II.1. They are followed by 19 blanck numbered leaves, after which the QdA begin.

origin.p: The watermark, a shield with three lilia couroned with flowers (particularly visible in the first guard leafs and at ff. 39, 87, 95, 116-117, 139, 188, 202, 204-205, 207, 256, 270, 295), is very similar to Briquet 1680, a variant of which was used in Paris in 1451. From 215-217, 221-222 variant with hook.

history.provenance: Just like ms. Amiens 405, it belonged to monastery of St. Pierre in Corby. On f. 1r, in the centre of the decoration, a later (17th century) hand wrote: monasterii sancti Petri Corbeiensis.

listBibl.bibl: Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France. Départements – tome XIX : Amiens, 191-192.

msItem.title: QsE (I–X)
msItem.colophon: Expliciunt questiones super primo Ethicorum, 1471

origin.p: Dating stated in the colophon of the first book: Expliciunt questiones super primo Ethicorum, 1471, f. 14r.

The first part of this manuscript, containing Versoris's commentary, was copied in Basel. The manuscript was bound in Basel together with an incunable printed in 1475, as attested by the binder's stamp of Pancratius Hochberg of Basel.

provenance.p: The codex belonged to Ambrosius Allantsee, with whom it arrived in 1491 at the Benedictine convent of St. Mang in Füssen. On the inner front cover, there is an ex libris: Sancti Magni in Fuessen. A later ex libris indicates that the manuscript subsequently came into the possession of the library of the Church of Saints Ulrich and Afra in Augsburg.

listBibl.bibl: H. Hilg, Lateinische mittelalterliche Handschriften in Folio der Universitätsbibliothek Augsburg: Cod. II. 1.2o 91–226, Wiesbaden, 1999, p. 375–377

msItem.title: QsE
msItem.note: The text ends unfinished at book IX, question Utrum amare seipsum secundum rationem sit laudabile, with the words: Nam loco bonorum exteriorum eligit bonum virtutis, quod est maximum, et sic.

origin.p: This dating appears in the colophon of Aristotle’s Nicomachean Ethics (2r-150r): Anno Domini 1493, f. 150r.

The codex is the fourth and final part of a collection containing Aristotle’s corpus, with the first three volumes transmitting the Metaphysics, logic, and natural philosophy. The four volumes were copied between the years 1492 and 1493.

history.provenance: The manuscript belonged to Bamberg Chapter library

msContents.summary: The commentary is ascribed to Versoris in the first colophon

msItem.title: QsDente
msItem.note: The commentary is ascribed to Versoris in the colophon: “Explicit scriptum Versoris super De ente et essentia sancti Thome doctoris”.
msItem.colophon: Explicit scriptum Versoris super De ente et essentia sancti Thome doctoris

origin.p: In the colophon of f. 35r (Henricus Collis’s Sermones contra articulos plebanorum Argentinensium), we read that the text was copied in 1456: Scriptum per me, fratrem Nicolaum Unbehuen de Bamberga in Ulma, tunc temporis magister studentium, anno Domini 1456 in quadragesima. The date 1465 likely appears in the second colophon of Versoris’s commentary, though it is difficult to confirm because the colophon has been deleted. However, I could distinguish the first words: Explicit De ente et essentia magistri Versoris.
The manuscript was copied in Ulm by Nicolaus Unbehuen (as stated on f. 35r) or Umbehauen (as stated on f. 137r).

history.provenance: It belonged to the Dominican convent, as indicated on f. 1r: ordinis predicatorum.

listBibl.bibl: S. Włodek, “Thomas Sutton, De productione formae substantialis”, AHDLMA 46 (1979), 127- 175, at 129.

msItem.note: Ascription to Versoris can be found at the end of the first book of the Questions on De celo, f. 131ra. The colophon by the hand of Iohannes Scolaris reads: Et sic est finis primi De celi et mundi. Another hand added: Iohannis Versoris.
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis secundi De celo et mundo, in vigilia phipi Iacob anno Domini LXVIII°

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Iohannes Scholaris in 1458-59, just like ms. F III 11.

In the first part of the volume, the same watermark that can also be found in ms. F III 11, is quite similar (except for the lower part) to Piccard, Lilie, III 1453 (Metz, 1477); in the second part of the volume, a mermaid very similar to Briquet 13858 (Troyes, 1458-1461).

msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis textus Summularum magistri Petri Hispani ordinis Predicatorum, qui quidem completus est Parisius in collegio Tornacensi, anno incarnationis Domini 1463, per me, Christianum Lupi, magno cum labore

msItem.title: CsPH
msItem.note: Versoris’s commentary is preceded by the text of the Summule logicales (ff. 1r–63r).
msItem.colophon: finitius est liber Parisius, anno Domini incarnationis 1463, per me, Christianum Lupi

origin.p: Paris, as stated in the colophons: Et sic est finis textus Summularum magistri Petri Hispani ordinis Predicatorum, qui quidem completus est Parisius in collegio Tornacensi, anno incarnationis Domini 1463, per me, Christianum Lupi, magno cum labore, f. 63r; finitius est liber Parisius, anno Domini incarnationis 1463, per me, Christianum Lupi, f. 292v. Christianus Lupi later entered the franciscain convent in Brandeburg, which explains the presence of this codex in Berlin.

provenance.p: On f. 294v, we find the following ex libris: Iste liber spectat ad conventum Branderbugensis.

origin.p: The texts in this manuscript have been copied in Cologne and Trier by three scribes: Werner Wacker de Welstatt de Hirschhorn, Carmelite, student in Cologne from 1464 to 1472 and from 1474 to 1476, lector in Trier from 1473 to 1474 (Lickteig, German Carmelites, p. 454, 484); Theodericus Billinger de Darmstadt, Carmelite, studied in Cologne in 1463-1464 and 1467-1468 (Lickteig, German Carmelites, p. 453); Johannes Dinck.

msItem.title: QdA
msItem.note: Anonymous QdA. The first folio, probably containing an eluminure, has been ripped out. The collation of the QdA and the QPN with Johannes de Magistris’s commentaries enabled to identify the anonymous texts in the Colmar manuscript with them.

msItem.title: QSom
msItem.note: Should be attribute to another Parisian master, John of Caulaincourt.

origin.p: The texts were copied by Eberhardum Saltzmann de valle masonis, Masevaux, diocese of Basel.

1459, as stated in the colophon of QsP. Although, at the end of book I (f. 12v), we read (by a different hand) the date 1491, the previous dating is confirmed by the watermak: a P similar to Briquet 8593 (widespread, among other places, in Basel, 1461-1464, and in Strasbourg, 1463).

the volume consists of three parts (Metaph; Phy; QdA, PN) copied by different hands and presenting different watermarks. The QsM/QsP and the QdA/QPN are separated by a guard leaf. The QdA/QPN contain a watermark similar to Piccard Lilie I 683-686 (Frankfurt a.M., Aachen Cologne, Brugge, 1478-1481). Their origin seems therefore to be different from the parts containing the QsM and the QsP.
Many of the enluminures at the beginning of the books have been ripped out.
origin.note: The section transmitting the QsP contains the same watermark (Frucht similar to Piccard I 393-398) of ms. Basel, UB F VI 4

history.provenance: The manuscript belonged to the convent of the Dominicans of Guebwiller.

msItem.author: Lambertus de Monte

msItem.title: Copulata super libros de anima Aristotelis
msItem.author: Lambertus de Monte
msItem.note: Cologne, Heinrich Quentell, 1494

msItem.title: Positiones circa libros phisicorum et de anima Aristotelis
msItem.author: Lambertus de Monte
msItem.note: Cologne, Heinrich Quentell, 1494

origin.p: Shortly before 1495. This dating can be inferred from the watermarks, the note on the inner back cover, and the dates of the printed works bound in the volume, namely Lambertus de Monte’s Copulata on Aristotle’s Physics (Cologne, Heinrich Quentell, 1493; Hain 1686, GW M16784) and De anima (Cologne, Heinrich Quentell, 1494; Hain 1713, GW M16775), as well as the Positiones circa libros Phisicorum et De anima Aristotelis (Cologne, Heinrich Quentell, 1494; Hain 13303, GW M35127).

The manuscript was owned by Petrus Hunlin de Lindaw, a student in Heidelberg, who purchased it in 1495. On the inner back cover we read: Iste liber est beate virginis Marie in Salem, comparatus per fratrem Petrum Hienlin, ibidem professum pro 1 ½ florenis et VII albis cum ligatura 1495to.

listBibl.bibl: W. Wilfried, Die mittelalterlichen nichtliturgischen Handschriften des Zisterzienserklosters Salem, Wiesbaden 2000, p. 156–157.

msContents.summary: The commentaries are ascribed to Versoris in the note on the inner front cover and in the table of contents on the first guard leaf: in isto libro continentur primo questiones magistri Versoris super Porphirium, item Predicamente Aristotelis….

origin.p: After the suppression of the monastery in 1808, the codex arrived at the Tirol University Library. On the inner front cover we read: Dicta Versoris super totam loycam. Liber virginis gloriose in Stams, comparatus per me, fratrem Melchior de Ymbst, per iii florenos, in alma universitate Heidelbergensi, anno Domini MCCCCLXXII, tunc temporis occupantem studium. [a.m.:] Frater Balthazar de Ymbst, venerabilis fratris Melchior confrater carnalis necnon spiritualis, qui docti fuerunt et ad iustitiam erudiverunt multos, fulgebunt quasi stelle in perpetuas eternitates. This information also appears in other places of the codex, such as in the first guard leaf: frater Melchior de Stans, anno Domini etc. LXXII occupavit studium alme universitatis Haidelbergensis, and on ff. 264v: Stams me possidet liber dicit iste. Melchior de Stams me comparavit. Melchior me emit. On the back guard-leaves students at Heidelberg University in 1472 and 1488 are listed (Anno Domini MCCCCLXXII studentes apud sanctum Iacobum extra muros alme universitatis Heidelbergensis; Anno nostre salutis autore millesimo CCCCmo 88vo fuere studentes apud sanctum Iacobum extra muros Haydelberge; the list of the students can be consulted in the modern catalogue description).
origin.note: and present similar watermarks, possibly indicating a common origin.

provenance.p: The codex belonged to Melchior Bosch from Imst, who studied at Heidelberg University and later entered the Cistercensian monastery of Stams. It later came into the possession of Balthasar Bosch, from the same family as Melchior, who also studied at Heidelberg University and entered the Cistercensian monastery of Stams.

listBibl.bibl: K. Walsh, “Zwei Stamser Zisterzienser an der Universität Heidelberg: Melchior und Balthasar Bosch aus Imst als Besitzer von Innsbruck, Universitätsbibliothek Cod. 220, und ihr Freundeskreis”, in Kulturerbe und Bibliotheksmanagement. Festschrift für Walter Neuhauser (Biblos-Schriften 170), Innsbruck 1998, 89–122

C. Schretter-Picker, “Libri Stamsenses. Anfang und Werden der mittelalterlichen Büchersammlung des Zisterzienserstiftes Stams”, in J. Hörmann-Thurn und Taxis, T. Pamer, J. Schwarz (edd.), Anfang und Werden –– Stift Stams im Mittelalter. Vorträge der wissenschaftlichen Tagung anlässlich des 750-Jahr-Jubiläums des Zisterzienserstiftes Stams 1273–2023. msItem.author: Joannes Versoris
msItem.note: Printed in Cologne by Heinrich Quentell before 1489

msItem.author: Joannes Versoris
msItem.note: Printed in Cologne around 1487

msItem.title: QsPor
msItem.note: These questions are preceded by two incunabula: 1. Versoris’s Questions on the Ars nova and De ente et essentia; 2. Versoris’s Questions on the Ars vetus (Isagoge, Predicamenta, De interpretatione, De sex principiis) and followed by two anonymous manuscript copies of commentaries on the Ars vetus: a set of Questions on Porphyry’s Isagoge

msItem.title: Questions on Porphyry’s Isagoge
msItem.incipit: Circa initium Porphyrii queritur primo utrum logica rationalis scientia specialiter ab aliis scientiis sit distincta. Pro cuius questionis determinatione tria sunt videnda
msItem.explicit: penes modum essendi et predicandi de multis distinguuntur

msItem.title: Questions on Aristotle’s Predicamenta
msItem.incipit: Circa initium libri Predicamentorum Aristotelis queritur primo utrum de predicamentis sit scientia. Pro quod sciendum primo quod, quia scientia est habitus intellectualis, videndum est quid sit habitus, quot sunt et quomodo distinguuntur
msItem.explicit: supplet vicem speciei intelligibilis; est tamen sciendum…

origin.p: The dating of the incunabula bound together in the codex (around 1487–89; see the section on content) and the list of lectures attended by Iacobus from 1497 to 1500 (f. 204r) suggest that the volume was assembled at the end of the fifteenth century.

history.provenance: The codex belonged to Iacobus Borkeman de Mariaeburgo, as indicated by the possession mark on the upper margin of f. 2r: Iacobi Borkeman Mariaenburgensis sum.

msItem.title: QsSE
msItem.note: The manuscript also contains Laurentius de Poznania’s literal commentaries on Aristotle’s Prior Analytics (ff. 1r–75r), Posterior Analytics (ff. 79r–135r), and De anima (ff. 148r–158r), as well as a fragment from his literal commentary on the Sophistical Refutations (f. 135v). In addition, it includes a copy of Aristotle’s Sophistical Refutations with some anonymous marginal and interlinear glosses (ff. 198r–252v), and an anonymous literal commentary on Aristotle’s Prior Analytics (ff. 136r–146v).
msItem.colophon: Anno Domini millesimo quadrigentesimo septuagesimo septimo

origin.p: 1477, as evident from the colophon: Anno Domini millesimo quadrigentesimo septuagesimo septimo, f. 286v.

msItem.title: Circa tertium De celo et mundo queritur utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis possit concludi nullum corpus esse compositum ex indivisibilibus
Utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis numerus quaternarius sit elementorum
Utrum elementa secundum se tota sint generabilia et corruptibilia

note.p: Versoris’s QdC I–II, IV are completed by some questions on Book III, copied without codicological discontinuity between Book II and Book IV of Versoris’s commentary. The questions are as follows: Circa tertium De celo et mundo queritur utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis possit concludi nullum corpus esse compositum ex indivisibilibus, f. 126rb; Utrum omnium corporum sit generatio, f. 127r; Utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis numerus quaternarius sit elementorum, f. 128r; Utrum elementa secundum se tota sint generabilia et corruptibilia, f. 128v. The same questions have been interpolated into Versoris’s QdC in ms. BJ 2024.
The QsMete are preceded by the prologue of Paulus of Worczyn’s Questions on Aristotle’s Meteorology.

To complete the set of commentaries on Aristotle’s libri naturales, the codex also contains the anonymous Cracovian QsP (inc.: circa initium libri Physicorum queritur utrum inter tres scientias speculativas reales philosophia ordine doctrine sit prima, mathematica secunda, metaphysica tertia”) and some anonymous QdG (ff. 135r–163r, the same that can be found in ms. 2118, ff. 177r–193r).
The commentaries are accompanied by several glosses.

list.item: Kraków, BJ, cod. 2024, in which Versoris’s QdC are also completed with the same anonymous questions on Book III

msItem.title: QsP
msItem.author: Anonymus
msItem.incipit: circa initium libri Physicorum queritur utrum inter tres scientias speculativas reales philosophia ordine doctrine sit prima, mathematica secunda, metaphysica tertia

list.item: Krakow, BJ, cod. 2002, 2072, 2087, which contain the same Cracovian QsP.
Kraków, BJ, cod. 2118, which contains the same anonymous QdG found at ff. 135r–163r.
Munich, BSB, Clm 520, in which Versoris’s QsMete are also preceded by the prologue from Paulus of Worczyn’s Questions on Aristotle’s Meteorology.

origin.p: Based on the watermarks, the part containing Versoris’s commentaries can be dated to the third quarter of the fifteenth century. I am referring to the typescript description prepared by Marian Zwiercan in 1961, which was kindly made available to me by the librarians of the manuscript department.
origin.note: Kraków, BJ, cod. 2085, which also belonged to Michael de Turobin.

history.provenance: The codex belonged to Michael de Turobin: Liber Michaelis Lublin, alias de Turobin, decretorum doctoris, decani Cureloviensis, canonici Lovicensis et fundatoris ecclesie Collegialis ad sanctam Annam Cracovie, datus in usum pauperum studiosorum, qui obiit 1528, 24 Aprilis, f. 1r.

listBibl.bibl: Panzica, “Commenter les Météorologiques à l’Université de Cracovie”, 122–124, 125, 178.

msItem.title: Qdente
msItem.author: Johannes Versoris
msItem.note: Versoris’s questions are followed by some anonymous QdC (ff. 25r–40v); QdG (ff. 40v–53r); QsE (ff. 53r–107r); Puncta on the Metaphysics (ff. 110v–171v); QsTop (ff. 175r–216r).

origin.p: 1460. This date appears in the colophon of some anonymous Puncta on Books I–XII of Aristotle’s Metaphysics, as well as on the first guard leaf, both by the same scribe.

Probably Krakow. Part of this manuscript was copied by Baltasar from Poznań in 1460: Expliciunt puncta Metaphysice, per me, Baltasar de Poznania, finita feria tertia proxima ante festum sancti Gregori, sub anno Domini M°CCCC° sexagesimo, f. 171v. The name of this scribe and the date also appear on the first folio: Pisana przez Baltara z Poznania, 1460 roku.

provenance.p: The manuscript belonged to a master named Kazuchowski, as we read at f. 1r: Mathie, liber magistri artium Kazuchowski.

msContents.summary: The table of contents at f. 1r ascribes the first set of Questions on De anima to Versoris, and describes the Questions on the Parva naturalia as written according to the via antiqua: Liber magistri Andree de Gąbyn. Questiones Versoris super libros De anima; Questiones alie breves super libros De anima; Questiones super Parva naturalia de via antiquorum; Liber de differentia spiritus et anime; Problemata. The ascription to Versoris of the first set of questions is found again at f. 2r (Questiones Versoris super De anima), but neither the incipit, nor the explicit, nor the list of questions corresponds to Versoris’s commentary.

msItem.title: QsSens
msItem.note: These commentaries are preceded by two anonymous sets of questions on Aristotle’s De anima (ff. 2r–81v and ff. 82r–111r). A set of Problemata (ff. 188r–218r) completes the volume.
Versoris’s commentaries are accompanied by quite dense marginal glosses.

msItem.title: QdLong
msItem.colophon: anno Domini 1473

origin.p: Versoris’s commentaries were copied in 1473, as evident from the colophon (anno Domini 1473, f. 150v). The Problemata at the end of the volume were copied in 1467: Et sic est finis huius. Laudatur etiam Sanctus Bartholomeus, anno Domini 1467, per me, baccalarium de Falkenberg, f. 218r.

A bachelor from Falkenberg signed the colophon of the last text. The exact identification of this place name is uncertain, as several towns called existed in late medieval Germany (e.g., in Brandenburg, Saxony, and Bavaria). Given the strong presence of German students from these regions at the University of Kraków during the 15th century, the reference may plausibly point to one of the Saxon or Brandenburg Falkenbergs, though a precise identification cannot be established.

provenance.p: The codex was partly copied by and belonged to the master Andrea de Gąbyn, as stated in the colophon at f. 184v (per Andream de Gambyn, ipso die, etiam ante Penthecostem, anno Domini 1473) and in the possession mark at f. 1r.

msItem.title: QsE I–X
msItem.note: The commentary is accompanied by marginal notes in hands different from that of the main text.
msItem.colophon: Finitus anno Domini 1469, per fratrem Johannem comparatus

origin.p: The colophon records that the copy was completed in 1469: Finitus anno Domini 1469, per fratrem Johannem comparatus (f. 186r).

provenance.p: The codex (or sam of ist parts) belonged to the Krakow masters Andreas de Paradiso (magistri Andree de Paradiso, f. 193v, marg. sup.), Petrus Zambrzecz (first inside cover: tres sexterniones aput magistrum Petrum Zambrzecz), and Stanislaus Białkowski (first guard leaf: magistri Stanislai Bialkowski).

msItem.title: Circa tertium De celo et mundo queritur utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis possit concludi nullum corpus esse compositum ex indivisibilibus
Utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis numerus quaternarius sit elementorum
Utrum elementa secundum se tota sint generabilia et corruptibilia

note.p: Versoris’s QdC I–II, IV are completed by some questions on Book III, copied without codicological discontinuity between Book II and Book IV of his commentary. The questions are as follows: Circa tertium De celo et mundo queritur utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis possit concludi nullum corpus esse compositum ex indivisibilibus, f. 333r; Utrum omnium corporum sit generatio, f. 334r; Utrum ex parte gravitatis et levitatis numerus quaternarius sit elementorum, f. 334v; Utrum elementa secundum se tota sint generabilia et corruptibilia, f. 335r. The same questions have been interpolated into Versoris’s QdC in ms. Kraków, BJ, cod. 2007.

To complete the set of commentaries on Aristotle’s libri naturales, Versoris’s texts are preceded by John Breslawer de Brunsbgerga’s QsP (ff. 1r–259v) and followed by Andreas Ruczel de Costen (Kościan)’s QdA (ff. 400r–439r).

list.item: Kraków, BJ 2024, in which Versoris’s QdC are also completed with the same anonymous questions on Book III.

msItem.title: QdG
msItem.colophon: Explicit liber secundus De generatione et corruptione sub anno Domini 1478, in die Mathie ante reminiscere, feria quarta, etc.

origin.p: 1478, as stated in the colophon of the QdG: Explicit liber secundus De generatione et corruptione sub anno Domini 1478, in die Mathie ante reminiscere, feria quarta, etc., f. 294r.

provenance.p: A mark of possession on the inner front cover indicates that the codex belonged to the Kraków master Clemens de Gambycze (Apud executores testamenti olim venerabilis viri maystri Clementis de Gambycze per eundem).

msItem.title: QsMeta
msItem.author: Antonius Andreae
msItem.colophon: Expliciunt questiones Anthonii Andree, ordinis minorum, correpte ac emendate per excellentissimum magistrum Franciscum de Nerithono, ordinis predicatorum, reportate in studio Cracoviensi per Martinum de Tarnoviecz, finite die Saturni immediate ante Galli in Maiori collegio, anno reparationis nostre 1489

msItem.title: Qdente
msItem.note: The text is preceded by Antonius Andreae’s QsMeta (ff. 4r–103r), followed by anonymous QsMeta (ff. 110r–185v) with marginal glosses, and then by Giles of Rome’s Questions on De ente et essentia (ff. 221v–243v).
msItem.colophon: terminate sunt hee questiones, propositiones Egidii Romani sub annis Domini tunc currentibus 1479

msItem.title: Questions on De ente et essentia
msItem.author: Giles of Rome
msItem.colophon: Martinus de Tarnoviecz scripsit, clericus Cracovie, infra caniculam

origin.p: The texts in this manuscript were copied between 1479 and 1489, as indicated by the colophons: Expliciunt questiones Anthonii Andree, ordinis minorum, correpte ac emendate per excellentissimum magistrum Franciscum de Nerithono, ordinis predicatorum, reportate in studio Cracoviensi per Martinum de Tarnoviecz, finite die Saturni immediate ante Galli in Maiori collegio, anno reparationis nostre 1489 (f. 103r); 1480 (f. 199r); terminate sunt hee questiones, propositiones Egidii Romani sub annis Domini tunc currentibus 1479 (f. 243r).

Versoris’s text was copied in Cracow by Martinus de Tarnowiecz, as stated in the colophon: Martinus de Tarnoviecz scripsit, clericus Cracovie, infra caniculam (f. 221r). Martinus later owned the volume, as attested by a note on f. 1r, written when he had already attained the title of master: ego magister Martinus, 1501.

msItem.title: QdLon
msItem.note: only the beginning of q. 1; ends interrupted after the oppositum, with the words: Pro responsione est primo sciendum quod

origin.p: The watermarks were attested in the years 1447–1457 I am referring to the typescript description prepared by Marian Zwiercan in 1961, which was kindly made available to me by the librarians of the manuscript department.

provenance.p: The manuscript belonged to Albert de Szurkowo, who studied in Paris and donated the codex to his heirs (f. 67rb: Liber reverendi magistri Alberti inclite Universitatis Parisiensis, heredibus de Szurkovo, multum pauperis, etc., ille legat comissa, deosque precetur et oret, ut redeat miseris, abeat fortuna superbis). It subsequently came into the possession of the Master Iohannes de Iuniwladislavia (f. 1r: Questiones cum lectura De anima, De ente et essentia et alia magistri Iohannis de Iuniwladislavia).

msItem.title: QdA
msItem.note: It seems not to have been copied by Marcellus Geist.

msItem.title: QdC
msItem.note: It seems not to have been copied by Marcellus Geist.

origin.p: Date as evident from the colophons: Hanc determinavi questionem feria quarta, post decollationem Iohannis Baptiste, anno domini 1449, de mane, presidente magistro Iohanni Buschbach, sui magister unius anni cum dimidio, f. 240ra; Hec questio determinata est per magistrum Marcellum Geyst, anno millesimo quadrigentesimo quinquagesimo, sexta feria ante nativitatis Marie, in tertio anno magistratus ipsius, f. 258va; edita a magistro Marcello, anno LII
This codex contains texts copied by Marcellus Geist, who studied and taught at Heidelberg University until 1452. In 1454, he entered the Carthusian Order and was appointed prior in Mainz in 1470.

history.provenance: After Marcellus death, the codex passed into the possession of the library of the Mainz Carthusians.

msItem.title: CsPH
msItem.note: Book I ends unfinished on f. 62v with the treatment of modal propositions bene variantur specie accidentali et ex parte affirmationis et negationis. The scribe wrote afterwards: require in fine libri †. Books V and VI are missing.
Versoris’s commentary alternates with the text of Peter of Spain’s Summulae, which is copied in larger characters with increased interlinear spacing.

origin.p: Date as read at the end of book V of Peter of Spain’s Summulae, f. 193r.

The manuscript was copied and owned by the monk Heinrich Erlbach, from the benedictine monastery of Saint Emmeram in Regensburg. His name appears in the colophons: frater Henricus ordinis divi Benedicti, f. 181v; Heinricus Erlbach, tunc temporis scolaris veteris cappelle Ratisbonensis, f. 274v.

msItem.note: The QsMeta are preceded by an introduction, at ff. 86ra-va (inc.: “Girum celi circuitui sola Ecclesiastici 24. Doctrinalibus et naturalibus iuxta et corporis et ingenii ; expl.: regnator Olimpi, Olimpus pater Deus, Amen”.

on f. 93rb, marg. inf., we find an indication on the teaching practice: Non legitur primus tractatus Metaphysice, quia in ipso solum tractantur et reprobantur opiniones antiquorum de primis principiis et causis entium.

origin.p: The texts were copied by Petrus Lutcz de Schweygern and Johannes Ceyll.
The colophons inform us that the text were copied in 1468 (QsP and QdA), 1471 (QsMeta) and 1477 (QdLong).

Heidelberg, as stated in the colophon on f. 72va: Aratus autem hic est libellus per maystrum Petrum Lutcz de Schweyern, anno millesimo quadrigentesimo septuagesimo sexto, finitusque eodem in die Thome Cantuariensis martii altera, quod est in die Innocentium, in alma universitate Heidelbergensi.

history.provenance: The codex belonged to the Augustinian convent.

msItem.note: The text is acephalus and begins with the words: eius, sicut proprium consequitur speciem (book I). It ends unfinished at book V with the words: ergo quoddam corpus est ubique, quia.

origin.p: The watermark (a unicorn particularly visible in the last quire) is very similar to Piccard X, III, 2136 (Wesel, 1478) and 2137 (Wesel 1475).
Regensburg, as stated in the colophon on f. 93ra: Explicit quartus tractatus Petri Hispani de sillogismis, per manum fratris Leonhardi Schroter conventus Ratisponensis.

msItem.colophon: Et hec de questione presenti, et per consequens de toto primo libro Methaphisice Aristotelis, scripto et completo per me, Iohannem Quarreti, venerabilis nationis Francie, vicesima die mai
Et hec de questione, et per consequens de toto tertio libro Methaphisice Aristotelis, completo Parisius, secunda die mensis iunii, I. Q.

Et hec de questione presenti, et per consequens de toto quarto libro Methaphisice Aristotilis, completo Parisius, per me, Iohannem Quarreti, scolarem Parisius, studentem in artium facultati, anno Domini millesimo quadrigentesimo quadragesimo sexto

msItem.title: QsE I–VI
msItem.note: The QsE stops unfinished at f. 169v, question VI.7, Utrum synesis et gnomin sunt virtutes distincte adiuncte prudentie, with the words: sciendum est tertio, pro ampliori.

origin.p: 1446, as attested in the colophon of Book IV of the QsMeta: Et hec de questione presenti, et per consequens de toto quarto libro Methaphisice Aristotilis, completo Parisius, per me, Iohannem Quarreti, scolarem Parisius, studentem in artium facultati, anno Domini millesimo quadrigentesimo quadragesimo sexto, f. 54v.

The manuscript was copied in Paris by the student Iohannes Quarreti, as attested in the colophons of books I and III of the QsMeta: Et hec de questione presenti, et per consequens de toto primo libro Methaphisice Aristotelis, scripto et completo per me, Iohannem Quarreti, venerabilis nationis Francie, vicesima die mai, f. 12ra; Et hec de questione, et per consequens de toto tertio libro Methaphisice Aristotelis, completo Parisius, secunda die mensis iunii, I. Q., f. 34va.

listBibl.bibl: Rouse, Rouse, Illiterati et uxorati II,84

msContents.summary: The text is ascribed to Versoris in a note on the upper margin of f. 152r, written by the copyist: Questiones Versoris super sex libros Ethicorum. Bénédicte Sère tentatively ascribes the Questions on the Ethics transmitted at ff. 152r–215v to the master Wilhelm of Walma. However, Gauthier attributes these Questions to Versoris, suggesting that Wilhelm of Walma merely used Versoris’s Questions for his lectures.

msItem.title: QsE I–VI
msItem.note: Anonymous set of questions on the Ethics on books I–VI (ff. 2ra–151vb).

msItem.title: QsE (I–VI)
msItem.note: The text is ascribed to Versoris in a note on the upper margin of f. 152r, written by the copyist: Questiones Versoris super sex libros Ethicorum.

This commentary is preceded by an anonymous set of questions on the Ethics, again only on books I–VI (ff. 2ra–151vb). Interestingly, the last leaf of the commentary contains some notes on the subject matter of the seventh and the eighth book of Aristotle’s Ethics: De materia septimi libri, qui est de continentia et incontinentia, et de delectatione et tristitia, ut sunt earum obiecta [… ] Hoc Sanctus Thomas, prima secunde, questio 26, articulo tertio. […], f. 215va; In octavo huius. Amicitia est benivolentia qua bonum alteri voluimus […] Amicitia propter honestum est perfecta, f. 215vb. See Seńko, Repertorium, vol. 1, p. 108–111.
msItem.incipit: Circa primum librum Ethicorum Aristotelis movetur talis questio primo, utrum de virtutibus moralibus sit scientia. Et arguitur primo quod non: notitia que habetur de virtutibus moralibus est prudentia; ergo non est scientia. Consequentia tenet, quia scientia et prudentia sunt habitus distincti specie, ex sexto Ethicorum
msItem.explicit: quia prius oportet ostendere quod istud possit generare hominem
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis sexti Ethicorum, finiti per me, Claudium Verneti, dyocesis Bisuntiensis, studentem sub venerabili viro, magistro Galthero de Walma, actu Parisius regente in collegio Burgundie, in die Iovis penitentiali, hora quasi decima post prandium, anno Domini millesimo quadragentesimo sexagesimo tertio

origin.p: The colophon of the second set of questions on the Ethics informs us that it was copied by Claudius Vernet under the supervision of Galtherus de Walma, regent master at the Collège de Bourgogne: Et sic est finis sexti Ethicorum, finiti per me, Claudium Verneti, dyocesis Bisuntiensis, studentem sub venerabili viro, magistro Galthero de Walma, actu Parisius regente in collegio Burgundie, in die Iovis penitentiali, hora quasi decima post prandium, anno Domini millesimo quadragentesimo sexagesimo tertio, f. 215v.
origin.note: Berlin, SB – PK, lat. qu. 435; Wrocław, BU, Ms. IV F 1, also copied in the Collège de Bourgogne.

msItem.note: It ends interrupted with the words apparet nobis sit vere

msItem.title: QdLon
msItem.note: The QdLon are missing

layout.p: The manuscript presents the typical layout of Parisian volumes of the mid-fifteenth century: it is written in two columns; at the beginning of each commentary, the scribe left a quadrangular space intended to be filled with a squared initial, which, however, was never executed and remains blank.

origin.p: The manuscript is undated. A watermark appears throughout the volume—a fleur-de-lis (particularly visible on ff. 39, 59, 65, 66, 120–121, 137, 149, 207)—similar to Briquet 6911, attested in Paris in 1457, with a similar variant recorded in 1460. Another watermark, an anchor (visible on f. 101), is very similar to Briquet 391, attested in Bagé in 1452, as well as to Piccard II 516, attested in Brugges in 1452, and 517, attested in Mehelen in 1456.

The manuscript was copied by a single student, Simon de Horreo, in Paris, at the school of the master Iohannes Hameron, as attested by the colophons: QsP, final colophon, f. 82v; QdC, book I, 101rb; QdC, final colophon, 120vb; QsMete, final colophon, 223vb.
origin.note: Simon de Horreo highlights that the order in which the commentaries are copied does not correspond to the one in which they were taught, and reestablishes the correct order in two notes: Item secundum dictum ordinem librorum tres libri Metheororum qui iam hic sequuntur, immediate deberent precedere tres libros De anima et immediate sequi duos libros De generatione et corruptione, f. 193rb; and again, at the end of the QsM: Item notatur quod post istos tres libros sic completos bono ordine et congruo debent sequi tres libri De anima, et isti immediate sequuntur duos libros De generatione et corruptione, licet in compositione libri male observatur, f. 223v.

msItem.title: QsSE
msItem.colophon: Et hec de questione, et per consequens de toto primo Elenchorum, scripto [209vb] sub venerabili magistro Girardo de Watrellet, actu regente Parisius, in domo magistri Gaufridi Calvi, in vicesimam secundam mensis iulii, anno Domini Mmo CCCCmo LImo

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Yvo de Beisit, a student of Gerardus de Watrellet in the school of Gaufridus Calvi, as attested by the numerous colophons: QsInt, f. 96v; QsPri, book I, f. 116rb; QsPri,final colophon, f. 126va; QsPos, book I, f. 153vb; QsPos, final colophon: f. 164va; QsT, book I, f. 174vb; QsT, book II, f. 181vb; QsT, book IV, f. 185rb; QsSE, book I, f. 209va-b.

provenance.p: The manuscript later belonged to Iudicellus Rouyant, a Breton student at the Collège de Tréguier, who in 1456 transferred it to the master Reginaldus Du Brule as a pledge for tuition owed: Ista logica pertinet Iudicello Rouyant, scolari Britoni, commoranti in collegio de Triguier Parisius, quam tradidit magistro Reginaldo du Brule iuniori in pignus pro somma pecunie debita dicto du Brule per prefatum Iudicellum pro instructione et doctrina sucepta Parisius per prefatum Iudicellum in pedagogio dicti du Brule pro temporibus dimidii anni incipientis in festo nativitatis Iohannis Baptiste, anno Domini millesimo quadragentesimo LVIto, f. 1r. The manuscript was then returned to Iudicellus, who gave him to his uncle, Yvo Kentel, as recorded on f. 164va: reverendissimo meo avunculo, magistro Yvoni Kentel dedi. Scriptor scribebat: ex ‘I’ bene ‘o’ faciebat, pennam deposuit, et ‘o’ velud ante fuit, Iudicellus Rouyant.
Throughout the codex, additional ownership inscriptions are found: Iste liber pertinet Iohannes Geoffroy; Iohannes Ryetis, f. 36r; Ista logica pertinet Iohanni Laussardy, f. 228r.

listBibl.bibl: C. Samaran, R. Marichal, Catalogue des manuscrits en écriture latine portant des indications de date, de lieu ou de copiste, Tome III, Bibliothèque Nationale, fonds latin Nos. 8001 à 18613, Paris, 1974, 507.

origin.p: 1451, as stated at f. 128va (A. Kernynyven, Anno Domini M°CCCC° LI°, ) and at f. 359va (Anno Domini M°CCCC° LI°).

The whole manuscript was copied by Alanus Kernynyven, student at Paris Arts Faculty, who signed at the end of the works (end of QdC, f. 172va; end of QdG, f. 227vb; QsSen, f. 245vb; QdMem, f. 250vb; QdSom, f. 357rb), of the books (book I of QdC, f. 153ra, where appears also another name: Getholohan; book II of QsMete, f. 256va; book I of QdA, f. 273va), or of the questions (QdC, q. II.13, f. 158rb). On the inferior guard leafs other names can be read, probably new owners of the manuscript: De Ruppe, abbas; Jehan Mares.

msItem.title: Sincathegereumata
msItem.note: To these colophons of the texts ascribed to Versoris, we can add the other one by Johannem Abbatis.
msItem.colophon: Expliciunt Sincathegereumata magistri Petri Hyspani, Parisius scripta per me Johannem Abbatis, in collegio Marchie, anno Domini Mo CCCCo quinquagesimo, ultima die augusti. Heu male finivi, quia non bene scribere scivi.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied in Paris at the Collège de la Marche by Iohannes Abbatis, as attested by the numerous colophons. Dating attested by the numerous colophons providing rich information on the place, date and identity of the copyist.

provenance.p: On a guard-leaf pasted to the inner front cover we read: "Abbatis", and we find his signum. At f. 168v, we read: "Maistre Jehan Labbé". In the ornamented initial letter at f. 74r, we read: "I. Labbé". The manuscript was later acquired by a certain Iohannes de Bouberto, as attested in a possession mark at f. 168v: "Pertinet Johanni de Bouberto, testantibus Jo[hanne] de Piloriis, Petro de Suessione, J. de Montibus".

listBibl.bibl: Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France. Départements. Tome XXXIX. Reims, vol. II.1, Paris 1904, 210–211
Y.-F. Riou, Alfarabi, Aristote, Platon, Plutarque et Ptolémée à Reims vers 1479, Scriptorium, 49/1 (1995), 106–133, 116–118 who considers the scribe as the author of the commentaries

msItem.title: CsPH, II-III
msItem.note: On f. 1v, we find a list of Italian mottos, beginning with this one: Chi vuole de ogni cossa essere vincente / cum humilta se trouve patiente / chi spende piu che soa borsa non rende / non se l’abia amare se poverta lo prende. After this list, we find a note on Albert the Great’s conception of universals: nota, secundum Albertum, quod universale est triplex, scilicet ante rem, post re et in re. Universale ante rem est ipsa prima causa, comprehendens omnia tanta potentialiter in se ipsa; universale in re est ipsa natura communis induta aliqua materia et quantitate, particularizata in hoc et in hoc subiecto; universale post rem est ipsa natura terminis denudata a tali materia et quantitate subiecti que, postea apprehenditur ab intellectu per conceptum generis et speciei, habet formare de ipso qui postea conceptus, iunctis primis vocatur ‘secunda intentio’. Nota etiam: universale habet duplex esse, scilicet formale et materiale. Esse formale et obiective est quando habet esse in intellectu tantum; esse materiale et fundamentale est esse in suius singularibus.
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis Antepredicamentorum Aristotelis secundum lecturam parisiensem scriptam per me, fratrem Petrum Iohannem Balbum Ianuensem [scripsit: Ianuenses, sed correx.], ordinis predicatorum, in die Epiphanie, M°CCCC°LVIII°, hora XVIII
msItem.note: On f. 56rb, a short sentence schematically represents the Aristotelian categories: Aristoteles (sup. lin.: id est, substantia), magnus (quantitas), Philosophus (qualitas), Sifronici filius (relatio), disputando (actio), fatigatus (passio), in scolis (ubi), hodie (quando), sedet (situatus) coronatus (habitus).
Transmitted anonymously, but the colophon at f. 25ra specifies its Parisian origin. Versoris’s QsPH are not identified in Meirinhos, Bibliotheca, 399-400.

msItem.title: Incipit liber de intentionibus, fratris Francisci de Pratris, ordinis predicatorum
msItem.author: Franciscus de Prato
msItem.incipit: Que est necessitas ponenda speciem, secundum Philosophum in primo celi et mundi

msItem.title: QsApos
msItem.incipit: Circa primum librum Posteriorum Aristotilis movetur question talis, que est in forma talis, videlicet utrum de demonstration sit scientia tamquam de subiecto huius libri Posteriorum. Et arguitur primo quod non contra primum punctum tituli questionis, quia scientia est ingenerabilium et incorruptibilium, sed demonstrations sunt generabils est corruptibiles
msItem.colophon: Questiones sequentes super libro Posteriorum fuerunt composite per reverendum magistrum Richaldum de Bovillia ordinis predicatorum, artium et theologie doctorem

Et hec sufficiant de isto primo libro Posteriorum, quem composuit magister Richaldus de Bovilla, artium doctor eggregius [sic] et scripsit eum fratrer Petrus Iohannes Balbus ordinis predicatorum cum magna festinatione, M°CCCC°LVIII°, die XXI° Iunii, hora decima, cui domino sit merces hic per gratiam et in futuro per gloriam. Amen, in conventu nostro Papiensi
Et hec de questione, et per consequens de toto libro primo Posteriorum et secundo, lectis a magistro Richaldo de Bovilla, regente in facultate artium studii Dolanensis procuratorisque eiusdem
msItem.note: The introduction and the colophon of book I qualifie them as “composed” (composite) by the master Richaldus de Bovilla. They are presented as “thaught” (lecte) by this master in the colophon of book II. This information is confirmed by the collation. In fact, neither the incipit nor the list of question corresponds to Versoris’s text.

msItem.title: de demonstratione secundum sanctum Thomam
msItem.note: Treatise on demonstration
msItem.incipit: restat nunc dicere de demonstratione, cum enim scientia sit habitus conclusionis demonstate acquisitus ex ipsius speculatione

msItem.title: Incipit tractatus de reali et ente rationis secundum sacntum Thomam de Aquino ordinis predicatorum
msItem.incipit: Ut scias quid sit ens rationis et quid ens reale

msItem.title: Qdente
msItem.note: The Qdente are presented as “composed” (composite) by Versoris: Explicit liber utilis de ente et essentia compositus a magistro Iohanne Versoris supra textum sancti Thome de Aquino ordinis predicatorum, f. 115v.

msItem.title: QsP I-VI
msItem.note: At the end of book VII of the QsP, the scribe wrote that no copy of books VII-VIII was available to him: Et hec de questione, et per consequens de libro sexto Phisicorum finis omnibus. Et notetis quod non scribo alios duos libros, scilicet septimum et octavum, quia illorum copiam deficit, f. 193ra. The text is followed by a list of the most important propositions of the commentary (f. 193va: Iste sunt propositiones primi libri Phisicorum).

msItem.title: QdA
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis secundi libri De anima [erasit: per me fratrem Francischum de Rippa] ordinis predicatorum [erasit: conventus Mediolani, in secunda] die mensis octobris

Explicit tertius liber De anima secundum lecturam parisiensem, scripte [erasit: a me, fratre Francischo de Rippa, ordinis] predicatorum [erasit: conventus] Mediolani, provincie Lombardie ??] studente ibi ?? decima mensis octobris
msItem.note: Transmitted anonymously, but the colophon at f. 251ra specifies its Parisian origin.

origin.p: Composite manuscript, copied in the Dominican convents of Pavia and Milan, as evident from the colophons of the friars Petrus Iohannes Balbus (f.25ra) and Franciscus de Rippa (f.238va and f.251ra). These colophons are difficult to read because some important information about the scribes and the location of the copy has been erased.

The Dominican provenance of the codex is confirmed by the illumination at the beginning of the second treatise of the commentary on Petrus Hispanus (f. 2r), where St. Dominic is portrayed with a black mantle and a white tunic.
Most of the texts in this manuscript are of Parisian origin.
For the Italian didactic context of the confection of the volume, see f.1v.

The possession mark, on a piece of parchment from the original lost guard, states that the part of the volume containing the logical commentaries belonged to Petrus Iohannes Balbus, who copied it in 1458: Hoc commentum super artem veterem et philosofiam est mei, fratris Petri Iohannis Balbi Ianuensis ordinis Predicatorum, quod scripsi in diversis temporibus et ipsum finivi anno Domini M°CCCCLVIII° die Va iulii. Et omnia que in ipso continentur fuerunt extracta a libello valde incorrepto. On other old fragments, now pasted on the inner front cover, we read: Iohannis Balbi. Commentum supra philosophiam Aristotelis; Commentum supra philosophiam Iohannis Balbi fratris ordinis predicatorum. [a. m.] 1458.
The watermark, a flower, is similar to Piccard XII, II 967 (Pavia, 1448).

listBibl.bibl: Kaeppeli I, p. 395–397, n° 1122 (Franciscus de Prato).
Kaeppeli III, p. 302, n° 3464 (Richaldus de Bovilla).

origin.p: The date is attested by Philip Goupil in the numerous colophons, most of which bear precise date indication

The manuscript was copied by Philippe Goupil, a student in the house of Pierre Richier (Petrus Richeri), under the supervision of the master Clément Parmentier (Clemens Parmentarii), as indicated by the numerous colophons throughout the codex.

history.provenance: Two possession marks attest that the manuscript was owned by Iacob Pol, a student in Paris and later a friar at the Abbey of Saint-Bertin: Ista philosophia pertinet fratri Jacobi Pol, religioso ecclesiae sancti Bertini in Sancto Audomaro, Morinensis diocesis;Hunc librum acquisivit frater Jacobus Pol, tempore quo fuit scolaris Parisiensis

bibl.note: Suprisingly not in Lohr, Aristotelica gallica

listBibl.bibl: Livesey, Science in the Monastery. Texts, Manuscripts and Learning at Saint-Bertin, Turnhout 2020, 189-192 The texts are here presented as Questiones naturales of Aristotle and ascribed to Clémens Parmentier

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque d'Agglomération du Pays de Saint-Omer (Bibliothèque municipale)

msItem.title: QsP
msItem.note: Most of the QsP – particularly up to book III – display strong similarities with the questions ascribed to Versoris. However, with rare exceptions, most of the questions present a shortened text compared to the other copies. This process of simplification implies the elimination of the doubts (dubitationes) at the end of the questions, the reduction of the number of the conclusions, often reduced to the sole conclusio principalis, and the simplification of their structure, often limited to the enunciation of the main conclusion.

msItem.title: QdC
msItem.note: In the QdC the replies to the questions (including the notabilia, the conclusiones and the dubitationes) are missing. The arguments pro and contra are followed by the replies to the arguments.

msItem.title: QdG
msItem.note: The QdG represent a kind of a draft or repertoires of arguments, which mostly corresponds to the analogous arguments ascribed to Versoris. The question titles are followed by a series of arguments and their solutions. Question I.20, utrum elementa maneant formaliter in mixto, is the only one whose text is complete: it corresponds to the analogue question ascribed to Versoris.

msItem.title: QsMete
msItem.note: Only sporadically elements of the answer (notabilia) can be found. Differently from the QdG, the arguments are enounced altogether one after the other, as it is often the case in question commentaries, and the solutions are also grouped under the rubric "ad rationes". The arguments usually correspond to the ones found in the commentary ascribed to Versoris.

msItem.title: QdA
msItem.note: Most of the QdA are longer, as they usually (but not always) contain, beside the arguments and their solutions, the answer to the question, including some notabilia and conclusions (but not dubitationes). The text is different from the questions ascribed to Versoris.

msItem.title: QsLon
msItem.note: The questions on the Parva naturalia are again a repertoire of arguments and replies (presented in separate blocks). The arguments corresponds to those in the commentary ascribed to Versoris, but they are adapted in the new structure. For instance, in the first question, Utrum corpus animatum sit subiectum in libris parvorum naturalium, the reply to the first argument contains, in the commentary ascribed to Versoris, a reference to what has been said in the body of the question (“patet solutio ex dictis”). Since this part of the text is missing in the Saint-Omer manuscript, its content is summarized in the reply to the arguments, which, as a consequence, is much longer than in the commentary ascribed to Versoris.

origin.p: Dating attested in the final colophon: Et sic est finis libri De longitudine et brevitate vite, et per consequens de tota philosophia naturali Aristotelis, finita per me, fratrem Georgium de Brabantia, religiosum sancti Bertini, actu studentem Parisius in facultate atrium, anno Domini millesimo CCCC° LXX°, mensis Ianuarii, altera die festivitatis beati Pauli apostoli, hora fere prima post prandium. Deo laus. Tu qui suxisti de Virgine virgineum lac, regni celestis scriptorem participem fac, f. 115ra

The manuscript was copied by the benedictine monk Georgius de Brabantia, student at Paris Arts Faculty, as evident from the several signatures at the end of the texts (for instance, f. 11va, Frater Georgius de Brabantia; f. 56vb Georgius; f. 72vb, Georgius de Brabantia), colophons of the QsP the QdA (Et sic est finis tertii De anima, finiti per me, fratrem Georgium de Brabantia, actu studentem Parisius in facultate artium. Frater Georgius de Brabantia, f. 109va), the QdSom (Georgius de Brabantia, f. 114rb), the final colophon (transcribed below), as well as from the initium of the QdSom (Frater Georgius de Brabantia, f. 113ra). The name of Georgius de Brabantia also appears in the philaters of the illustrations found in several places of the manuscript, particularly at the beginning of the books. QsP, book II, f. 18ra: Et sic est finis secundi Phisicorum Aristotelis, finitus per manum Georgii Brabantie. Frater Georgius de Brabantia
At the end of book I QsP, definitions (Incipiunt diffinitiones et auctoritates primi Phisicorum)

provenance.p: The codex belonged to Carolus de Miraumont (1566-1637), a Benedictine monk at Saint-Bertin, whose name appears several times on f. 112rb et on f. 115rb

listBibl.bibl: Gil, Saint-Omer gothique. Les arts figuratifs à Saint-Omer à la fin du Moyen Age 1250-1550: peinture, vitrail, sculpture, arts du livre, Valenciennes 2004, 379
This manuscript is not mentioned in Charles Lohr's Aristotelica Gallica II, which skips directly from manuscript nr. 596 to 598 (p. 100-101)

origin.p: The part copied by Iohannes Nickel dates to 1465, as stated in the colophon of a set of anonymous QdA: Finis huius anno Domini M°CCCCLXV in profesto Mathei apostoli et ewangeliste [add. Petrus Nickel Lipsius per Iohannem Nickel], f. 90r.

The texts contained in this codex were copied by Iohannes Nickel from Oldernheim, enrolled at Leipzig in 1461 (ff. 4r–91v, 96r–173v, 178v, 179r–292v, 296r–387r), and by his relative Petrus Nickel (alias Schnorrenpeyl), scholar and clergyman in Heidelberg, who transcribed texts in this manuscript from 1525 onwards (ff. 1r–2v, 93r–95v, 174r–177v, 178v, 389r–394v). Versoris’s commentaries were copied by Iohannes Nickel and travelled from Leipzig to Heidelberg.

listBibl.bibl: Walz, Die historischen und philosophischen Handschriften, 210-215.not in Lohr.

msItem.title: Periermeneias
msItem.colophon: Terminantur Sentencie totius veteris artis in alma universitate studii Parisiensis questionatim collecte per Wenceslaum de Wrben, baccalarium arcium, ad universitatem Pragensem inde allate, magnam vim et intelligenciam textuum Philosophi in se lucide continentes. Scripte Prahae in collegio Sanctissime Marie Virginis anno Domini 1450 quarto ydus Octobris

msItem.title: Analytica priora
msItem.colophon: in collegio sanctissime Marie virginis Nacionis Bohemorum in domo Recek, anno etc. liii ante festum Venceslai tempore quo terminator presentis libri examen baccalariatus intravit ad gradumque sub reverend magistro Stanislao de Welwar terminativt, eodem anno sub decursu pauci temporis rex Ladislaus Pragam ingrediens in festo sanctorum Symonis et Iude in Castro Pragensi laudabiliter est coronatus.

msItem.title: Posteriora
msItem.colophon: Et sic est finis glose Parisiensis super utroque libro Posteriorum feria quinta ante Purificationem anno Domini 1454.

msItem.title: Elenchi
msItem.colophon: Et in hoc terminantur Parisiensia puncta in se continentia superficialiter cuncta que Aristoteles in suis libris oculte tradidit eosque ad legendum et non intelligendum edidit. … Terminantur puncta parisiensia super nova et veteri logica, comparata per Martinum de Glathovia anno etc. LII

origin.origPlace: Prague, as evident from the colophona.
